note.p: Located in East Baton Rouge Parish, Baton Rouge was founded as early as 1699 and serves as the parish seat. Baton Rouge became the capital of Louisiana in 1846. (Wikipedia; Britannica)

Located in Adams County, Mississippi, Washington was founded as early as 1797 in what was then unincorporated territory. It became part of the newly created Adams County on April 1, 1799. Washington served as the capital of the Territory of Mississippi from 1802 to 1817 and the capital of the State of Mississippi from 1817 until 1822, when it was replaced by Jackson. Presently, Washington is an unincorporated area that is not governed by a local municipal body. (Wikipedia; Rowland, Mississippi, 932; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: When the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it failed to abolish involuntary servitude. The amendment included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of African Americans, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies.

Immediately after the war, many states passed "Black Codes" or laws severely limiting African Americans' rights. Under these codes and other similar laws passed in the decades following the Civil War, African Americans could be arrested for any number of petty crimes, including vagrancy (functionally construed to mean any act of social mobility not approved by a white person) or theft (in Mississippi a felony if exceeding $10 worth of goods). Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality led to a dramatic expansion in the population of imprisoned individuals and an overwhelming number of African Americans within that population. Many states leased those convicted persons to private companies or individuals for their labor, and in certain cases lessees had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased.

Laborers worked in a variety of settings including shipbuilding and timber cutting, yet the most prominent form in states like Mississippi remained large-scale agricultural work. The convict lease system was incredibly dangerous and difficult for those who lived through it, as leased persons faced unsafe working conditions, inadequate living conditions, abuse from lessees, and grueling work schedules. Given these circumstances, the ready availability of imprisoned laborers, and the callousness of lessees and state officials, the mortality rate among convict laborers was incredibly high.

Certain states ceased leasing imprisoned persons to individuals or private companies in the late nineteenth century, only to continue using that labor on state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of African Americans while perpetuating anti-Black racism and laying the foundations of the modern prison-industrial complex (Library of Congress; Mississippi Encyclopedia).

While every southern state created a convict leasing program in the aftermath of the Civil War, few mirrored Louisiana's in scale and legacy. Following emancipation, Louisiana passed restrictive, heavily punitive laws to restrict African Americans' social mobility and labor, resting on the commonly-held racist stereotypes about African American criminality. To control both Black freedom and Black labor, the state of Louisiana began leasing its rapidly-swelling population of incarcerated African Americans to private individuals and companies. The vast majority of incarcerated African Americans were leased to perform agricultural labor, often for ex-Confederates, though many others labored in public works projects and varied other industries.

The largest convict leasing operation was located at Angola, a former enslaved labor camp owned by ex-Confederate Samuel L. James. Beginning with its lease in 1880, incarcerated persons at Angola, almost exclusively African American, labored on 28 acres of cotton fields while living in former enslaved dwellings. Like nearly all convict-leasing operations, those at Angola and throughout Louisiana presented the incarcerated with grueling labor, inadequate living conditions, and an alarmingly high mortality rate. After the abolition of the convict leasing system in 1898, the State of Louisiana purchased Angola in 1900 and made it the location of the Louisiana State Penitentiary. It remains today the largest maximum security prison in the nation with an inmate population that remains over 80% African American. The prison continues to produce revenue through several avenues, all deriving from incarcerated labor. Therefore while the convict leasing system in Louisiana legally ended, its legacy remains alive today (BlackPast).

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Louisiana State Penitentiary was located in Baton Rouge in 1835 and funded by leasing the facility to private owners who operated a convict leasing system at the penitentiary between 1830 to 1844. During the American Civil War, the penitentiary was between leases and under state control.

During Reconstruction, the Penitentiary continued to operate a convict labor and convict leasing system. These programs were devastating for Black Louisianans as the state's racially-specific adjudication of criminal procedure, funneled large numbers of freed Black Americans into the state's penitentiary system to perform unpaid labor for the state and private entities. (64 Parishes Encyclopedia)

div.p:
The State of Louisiana
vs { No 191
William E. Brewer

13th Judicial District Court
Parish of Tensas—

The accused, in this case, having been convicted by the verdict of the Court for the crime of Manslaughter, was brought into Court, and asked if he had anything to say why sentence should not now be pro-nounced upon him, and no cause to the contrary being shown, the following sentence was pronounced by the Court: By reason of the law and the evidence and the verdict of the Court being against the accused, It is ordered, adjudg-ed and decreed by the Court that you, William E. Brewer be re-manded to the custody of the sheriff of this parish; that you William E Brewer be remanded be taken to the Parish Jail, and there safely kept, and that the sheriff at the earliest day practicable deliver you to the keeper of the State Penitentiary, at Baton Rouge, and that you be there confined at hard labor
for the space of two years, and that you pay a fine of one dol-lar and costs of prosecution—
This read and signed in open Court this 28 day of April, A. D. 1870.
The within can be found at "Washington Adams County Miss—

E. L. Whitney shff
by Jno. W. Register
